I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

1. 
to Solomon Islands for subprogram 2 of the Economic Recovery Support Program.1 
 
2. 
The  Economic  Recovery  Support  Program  is  a  program  cluster  of  two  subprogram 
grants totaling $10.0 million.2 The program cluster aims to assist in making the adjustment to an 
economic  and  fiscal  deterioration  aggravated  by  the  global  economic  crisis.  Subprogram  2  of 
the program cluster will support improved fiscal management and structural measures that will 
aid  economic  recovery  and  place  the  economy  on  a  sustainable  medium-term  growth  path. 
Budget  support  will  help  protect  the  delivery  of  basic  services  to  the  vulnerable,  and  be 
complemented by actions to engage with key stakeholders. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The Solomon Islands economy has been among the most affected in the Pacific by the 
global economic crisis. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaged 7.3% per annum in the 
5 years to 2008. In 2009, GDP contracted by 1.2%. Solomon Islands returned to positive growth 
of  around  7.2%  in  2010.  While  economic  growth  rebounded  quickly,  medium-term  growth 
prospects  are  uncertain.  Stocks  for  the  key  industry—logging—are  expected  to  be  largely 
exhausted by the middle of the decade. The economy is also one of the most aid-dependent in 
the world.  
 
4. 
The  program  cluster  was  designed  to  support  the  Government  of  Solomon  Islands  to 
make short-term fiscal adjustments in response to the global financial crisis and lay a foundation 
for strengthening the medium-term reform agenda. Since its initiation, the program has helped 
the  government  weather  the  recent  global  economic  crisis  with  its  financial  position 
strengthened, largely due to the efforts made under the government’s reform program supported 
by  the  Core  Economic  Working  Group  (CEWG)  development  partners. 3  The  change  in 
government  in  late  2010  required  additional  time  to  resume  work  on  formulating  and 
implementing policy. The new government, however, remains strongly committed to continuing 
regular and systematic policy dialogue through the CEWG to support the reform program. The 
CEWG donor coordination model in Solomon Islands is considered to be a best-practice model 
of donor coordination in the Pacific.4 The government is now committed to improving the quality 
of public expenditure for better service delivery, as reflected in the government policy statement 
and the new National Development Strategy (NDS) 2011–2020 (currently being finalized). 
 
5. 
From  subprogram  1  to  subprogram  2. Subprogram 1, which was completed in 2010, 
achieved successful policy and institutional reforms. Solomon Islands satisfied all 19 conditions 
for  the  subprogram  1  grant  and  the  single  tranche,  totaling  $5  million,  was  fully  disbursed.5

Subprogram  2  continues  to  (i)  support  the  government  with  the  adjustment  costs  arising  from 
implementing an economic reform program to place the economy on a sustainable growth path, 
and (ii) facilitate a diversification of the economy away from unsustainable levels of logging and 
aid. It supports improved fiscal management and structural measures to ensure sustainability of 
the economic recovery and helps protect the delivery of basic services to the vulnerable. 
 
After  closely  consulting  with  the  government  and  accounting  for  evolution  of  priorities 
7. 
and policies, the prior policy actions for subprogram 2 were finalized, closely approximating the 
24 indicative triggers identified at the time of subprogram 1, with two modifications. One of the 
indicative triggers, regarding amendment of the bareboat charter law, was removed in light of a 
consensus  that  impediments  to  operation  of  the  franchise  shipping  scheme  had  been  more 
efficiently addressed with other measures. Another indicative trigger, concerning adoption of the 
Extractive  Industries  Transparency  Initiative  (EITI)  principles,  was  adjusted  to  recognize  that 
Solomon  Islands  has  officially  endorsed  the  principles,  with  the  consequential  legislative 
amendments  in  the  tax  regime  to  be  proposed  through  government  undertakings  in  the  grant 
agreement. All 23 prior policy actions and conditions in the policy matrix have been performed 
and satisfied, except for the adoption of NDS, which is at an advanced stage. ADB is currently 
supporting the government in preparing the NDS.8 Completion of the adoption of the NDS is a 
condition to the effectiveness of the grant agreement.   
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  expected  impact  of  subprogram  2  is  the  achievement  of  a  higher  and  more 
8. 
inclusive path of economic growth.  The expected outcome is to continue the positive trend of 
economic  recovery  with  protection  of  the  vulnerable  and  the  fiscal  position.  The  impact  and 
outcome are to be achieved through reforms in the four program outputs, leading to improved 
fiscal  management, an improved  enabling  environment for  the  private  sector, support  for the 
vulnerable,  and  strengthened  communication  and  ownership  of  policy  actions  by  the 
government and the general public.

Output  1:  Improved  fiscal  management.  This  output  is  directed  to  achieving  the 
medium-term goals of achieving overall fiscal discipline, providing strategic guidance to public 
financial  management  (PFM)  reform,  ensuring  effective  expenditure  controls  are  in  use, 
raising  the  efficiency  and  fairness  of  the  revenue  system,  and  improving  the  allocation  of 
public  resources  through  strengthened  budgeting  and  planning  processes.  This  output 
supports  short-term  fiscal  consolidation  while  seeking  to  maintain  the  capacity  to  fund 
essential  services  and  public  investment  over  the  medium  term.  The  output  also  helps 
address shortcomings in governance. The emphasis is on initiatives that address the weakest 
areas  of  PFM  identified  in  the  2008  public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability 
assessment.9 ADB operations have also provided additional technical support for achievement 
of output 1 through several TA projects.10 
 
11. 
Achieving  overall  fiscal  discipline.  Subprograms  1  and  2  provide  for  adherence  by 
the 2010 and 2011 budgets and the medium-term fiscal framework to the fiscal commitments 
of  the  Honiara  Club  Agreement 11  (or  any  updated  arrangement  put  in  place  with  the 
international community). Under subprograms 1 and 2, the government committed to keep the 
public debt–GDP ratio below 30% and to keep the ratio of payroll charges to GDP in 2010 to 
no  more  than  the  2009  level.  Under  the  agreement,  the  government  committed  to  (i)  avoid 
further  borrowing  or  sovereign  guarantees  until  the  government  reaches  green  light  status 
under  the  international  debt  distress  rating  system,  and  (ii)  maintain  a  fully  funded  recurrent 
budget  excluding  the  use  of  borrowing  to  fund  recurrent  expenditure.  There  has  been 
compliance with these fiscal provisions. 
 
The 2011 budget, which was approved by the Parliament on 11 April 2011, is consistent 
12.

continued  economic  expansion  and,  consistent  with  the  Honiara  Club  Agreement,  does  not 
envisage  new  sovereign  borrowing.  Due  attention  has  been  paid  to  supporting  the  delivery  of 
essential  services,  with  priority  given  to  maintaining  recurrent  budget  for  education,  health, 
transport,  and  grants,  such  as  provincial  grants,  at  original  2010  levels,  which  comfortably 
exceed  the  2009  benchmark  by  an  amount  greater  than  the  value  of  the  ADB  loan.  The

Significant fiscal risks nonetheless remain. The key risk factors in the budget include (i) 
the potential for an overestimation of domestic revenue, that is forecast to rise by 12.0%; (ii) the 
prospect of a decline in logging; and (iii) expenditure pressures that may arise from the need for 
the  government  to  accommodate  a  fractious  coalition,  which  may  result  in  a  series  of 
supplementary appropriations. The large wage and salary bill will remain an ongoing source of 
fiscal pressure, and may displace funding for investment and goods and services if the revenue 
outcome is less than expected.

lower transport operating costs.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Economic and Financial 

31. 
Economic  growth  prospects  for  Solomon  Islands  rest  on  the  private  sector  and  on 
developments in mining, agriculture, fishing, and, to a lesser extent, tourism. A large gold mine 
closed during the civil unrest has recently reopened in March 2011, and there is potential over 
the  longer  term  to  develop  large  nickel  deposits.  While  mining  projects  would  boost  GDP,  the 
sector would employ few people and there would be long lags before government revenue rose. 
The best prospects for job creation and for higher government revenue lie in large-scale palm oil 
developments,  in  fishing  (there  is  already  one  large  fish  cannery),  and  in  the  smallholder  tree 
crops  of  cocoa  and  copra.  The  supply  of  fruit  and  vegetables  to  the  urban  centers  as  a 
substitute for imports also offers good prospects, as does the fledgling tourism industry. 
 
32. 
A number of recent studies have examined the economic growth prospects allowing for 
different scenarios. The studies have identified the potential for economic growth after logging, 
albeit at only low to moderate rates that would see, at best, slow growth in real GDP per capita 
in  the  medium  term.  The  studies  have  also  highlighted  the  need  for  concerted  government 
action to realize the potential growth, and the risk of inaction. 
 
B. 

Governance 

33. 
Public  financial  management.  The  quality  of  public  sector  financial  management  has 
been improved in recent years. The government has embarked on a series of public expenditure 
reforms,  including  clearing  the  backlog  of  unaudited  central  government  financial  statements, 
introducing a medium-term fiscal framework, paying debt interest and trade creditor arrears, and 
increasing  revenue  collection.  However,  a  number  of  weaknesses  remain  in  public  sector 
financial  management  that  adversely  affect  public  service  delivery,  threaten  aggregate  fiscal 
discipline,  and  undermine  the  strategic  allocation  of  public  resources.  To  address  the 
weaknesses,  the  government  and  development  partners  continue  to  deepen  the  reforms  that 
simultaneously strengthen the government’s institutions and capacity.22 
 
34. 
Anticorruption.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained 
to  and  discussed  with  the  government  and  the  MOFT.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the legal documents and the grant regulations.
